questions.text: Hypercalcemia is associated with all of the following medical conditions except:
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is associated with all of the following conditions except hypothyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is however associated with hypercalcemia.

Other options:

1) Multiple myeloma is a hemotological malignancy associated with hypercalcemia.

2) Hyperparathyroidism is associated with sub-periosteal bone resorption resulting in hypercalcemia.

3)  Sarcoidosis is associated with hypercalcemia due to increased activity of 1 alpha hydroxylase activity in the macrophages.

questions.text: Which of the following can cause hypercalcemia in a patient?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A intoxication can cause hypercalcemia. This is due to high bone turnover. Ingestion of 50,000–100,000 units of Vitamin A daily can increase calcium levels up to 12–14 mg/dL.

Note: Vitamin D intoxication also leads to hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious by her neighbors. She is found to have marked dehydration and serum calcium levels of 16 mg/dl. All of the following can cause this presentation except:
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with severe hypercalcemia (> 14.8 mg/dl) is suggestive of a hypercalcemic crisis. Pancreatitis causes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. 

Hypercalcemic crisis is often caused by malignancies due to an acute rise in calcium levels following bone resorption due to metastases. It is a medical emergency that presents with polyuria, severe dehydration, gastrointestinal symptoms, and altered consciousness. It can lead to cardiac arrest and coma.

questions.text: Which of the following will not be seen in a patient with hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is associated with constipation and not diarrhea.

Nephrocalcinosis
Polyuria and dehydration
Renal failure
Musculoskeletal Bone pain, bone cysts
Myalgia and arthralgia
Osteopenia, osteoporosis

Nausea, vomiting, anorexia
Abdominal pain

Cognitive dysfunction
Drowsiness, obtundation, coma

Hypertension
Others Ectopic calcification 

The clinical signs associated with primary hyperparathyroidism can be remembered with the mnemonic 'stones, bones, abdominal groans, psychic moans'.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in patients following excessive intake of calcium?
questions.solution:
Excess calcium ingestion is not associated with restrictive cardiomyopathy. It results in milk-alkali syndrome, commonly associated with excessive intake of absorbable antacids such as milk or calcium carbonate.

In susceptible individuals, there is a loss of negative feedback, leading to excess calcium absorption when there is excess intake. It results in the following triad of clinical features:

  • Hypercalcemia 
  • Alkalosis - due to HCO3 reabsorption caused by PTH suppression, natriuresis, and water depletion.
  • Renal failure - due to damage to renal tubules.

It is reversible once ingestion of antacid is stopped. However, in severe cases, a chronic form called Burnett’s syndrome can develop. It is associated with irreversible renal damage.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Parathyroid adenomas are the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism.

Causes of primary hyperparathyroidism:

  • Parathyroid adenomas: These maybe
    • Solitary (more common) 
    • Multiple 
    • Part of MEN-1, MEN-2A or MEN-4
  • Chief cell parathyroid hyperplasia
  • Parathyroid gland carcinoma
  • Lithium use
  • Hyperparathyroidism-jaw tumor (HPT-JT) syndrome

Related Pearl: Parathyroid Diseases

questions.text: Which of the following sets of lab values will be seen in a patient with secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Secondary hyperparathyroidism presents with decreased calcium and increased levels of PTH, phosphate, and ALP.

In this condition, calcium deficiency leads to reactive stimulation of the parathyroid. It is caused by the following:

  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Vitamin D deficiency
  • Gastrointestinal malabsorption
  • Liver disease

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about primary hyperparathyroidism except:

choices.text: It causes prolongation of QT interval

questions.solution:
Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) causes shortening of the QT interval.

The asymptomatic form is the most common presentation in the Western population. But in developing countries, the patients are usually symptomatic. The classical symptoms and signs of PHPT are due to hypercalcemia as well as increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

questions.text: Calcitonin levels are increased in:
questions.solution:
Calcitonin levels are increased in hyperparathyroidism.

Due to elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels in hyperparathyroidism, there is osteoclast activation. This leads to increased calcium levels in plasma. As a response to this, there is an increase in the level of calcitonin to regulate the high calcium levels.

Calcitonin is secreted by the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland. Its principal effects are to lower serum calcium and phosphate by its action on bone and kidney. In bone, calcitonin inhibits osteoclasts and reduces bone resorption. In the kidney, it inhibits the reabsorption of both calcium and phosphate.

Other options

Option A: In hyperthyroidism, the direct effect of thyroid hormones can lead to bone resorption and mild hypercalcemia. However, hyperparathyroidism is a better answer.

Options B and D: Hypoparathyroidism and Cushing’s syndrome will have low serum calcium and hence, will not have increased calcitonin levels.

questions.text: The spinal x-ray of a patient with elevated ALP levels is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above x-ray shows a rugger jersey spine which is a distinct feature of hyperparathyroidism. It is associated with elevated ALP.

It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey. 

Option A: Paget's disease causes cortical thickening, which results in increased opacity on all sides of the vertebral body. These are called picture frame vertebrae.

Option C: Osteopetrosis presents with normal ALP levels. It results in sclerotic endplates of vertebrae that are termed sandwich vertebrae. Though this finding is similar to rugger jersey spine, it is denser and more sharply defined than rugger jersey spine. In addition, there is sclerosis of inner margins of vertebral bodies, resulting in a bone within a bone appearance.

Option D: Ankylosing spondylitis produces a bamboo spine appearance due to fusion of vertebral bodies.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with worsening pain and an inability to bear weight on her left leg. She says that she had banged her leg against a chair 3 days ago. X-ray reveals a fracture of her left tibia. In view of this finding, a skeletal survey was performed and reveals the following additional finding. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a pathological fracture of the tibia. The given x-ray shows brown tumors or osteitis fibrosa cystica, which are characteristic of hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: This x-ray finding in a patient is characteristic of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The arrows in this x-ray point to arrow-headed fingers or the spade phalanx sign. It is pathognomonic of acromegaly. 

Acromegaly is the result of excessive growth hormone (GH) production, most commonly from a macroadenoma of the pituitary. There is osseous enlargement, presenting with spade-like hands and widening of the terminal phalangeal tufts, giving an arrow-head appearance.

Other features in the hand include:

  • Widened joint spaces (due to cartilage hypertrophy)
  • Generalized osteoporosis and cystic changes in the carpal bones

Option A: Hyperparathyroidism causes subperiosteal bone resorption, which is marked along the radial aspect of the middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers.

Option B: Down's syndrome can cause hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger.

Option C: Psoriasis causes a pencil-in-cup appearance of the distal phalanx.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to treat a patient with hypercalcemia due to primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids have no effect on the serum calcium concentration in primary hyperparathyroidism and normal individuals. 

They are effective in the treatment of hypercalcemia when associated with the following conditions:

  • Malignancy
  • Vitamin D intoxication
  • Sarcoidosis

Initial medical management of hypercalcemia involves the following:

  • Normal saline (200-500 ml/hour): It is the mainstay treatment to correct dehydration, and titrated to maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hour
  • Pamidronate or zoledronate: These are bisphosphonates and are considered as the drug of choice in primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Cinacalcet: This is a calcimimetic that increases the affinity of the glands to extracellular calcium, thereby decreasing parathyroid hormone secretion
  • Denosumab: This inhibits RANK-ligand, which acts on osteoclasts
  • Calcitonin: This is an activated vitamin D analog that may be used to reduce calcium levels. It should be used within the first 24 hours

Forced diuresis refers to aggressive fluid hydration with loop diuretic administration. Although this is an effective method to reduce calcium levels, it requires careful monitoring for adverse effects like fluid overload, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesia. Due to this reason as well as the availability of more effective treatment modalities, forced diuresis is not preferred any longer.

The definitive management of primary hyperparathyroidism is the surgical removal of the parathyroid gland.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of hypercalcemia due to Vitamin D toxicity?
questions.solution:
In patients with hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity, glucocorticoids like dexamethasone are the preferred therapy as they decrease 1,25 (OH2) vitamin D (calcitriol) production. This results in reduced intestinal calcium absorption and increased urinary excretion of calcium.

Hydroxychloroquine, chloroquine, and ketoconazole may also decrease calcitriol production and are used occasionally. But the preferred therapy is steroids.

Vitamin D toxicity presents acutely with features of hypercalcemia such as confusion, polyuria, polydipsia, anorexia, vomiting, and muscle weakness. Chronic intoxication may cause nephrocalcinosis, bone demineralization, and pain.

Lab features include elevated 25 (OH) vitamin D, high calcium, and suppressed PTH.

Dexamethasone can also be used in the treatment of hypercalcemia caused by the humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (due to PTHr) and sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department with confusion, drowsiness, and multiple episodes of vomiting. His family members say that he was diagnosed with bipolar disorder several years ago and has been on medication ever since. Further evaluation reveals a serum calcium level of 16 mg/dl. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a hypercalcemic crisis. The next best step in management is saline hydration. Typically 200-500 ml/hour fluids are given to correct dehydration and titrated to maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hour.

Hypercalcemic crisis is a medical emergency associated with serum calcium >14 mg/dl. It is often caused by conditions causing an acute rise in calcium levels such as malignancies or lithium overdose.

It presents with oliguria, severe dehydration, gastrointestinal symptoms, and altered consciousness. It can lead to cardiac arrest and coma.

Initial medical management of hypercalcemia involves the following:

  • Fluids are the mainstay treatment
  • Bisphosphonates
  • Cinacalcet
  • Denosumab
  • Calcitonin

questions.text: In a patient with hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, which of the following will you not suspect?
questions.solution:
Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 1 is associated with hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia

Hypocalcemia with hyperphosphatemia is observed in the following conditions:

  • True hypoparathyroidism
    • Hereditary hypoparathyroidism
    • Acquired hypoparathyroidism – following surgery
    • Hypomagnesemia
  • Pseudohypoparathyroidism
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • DiGeorge syndrome

questions.text: All of the following medical conditions are associated with hyperphosphatemia except:
questions.solution:
Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism is a type of pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1A associated with normal calcium and normal phosphate. The clinical features are similar to pseudohypoparathyroidism but there is no PTH resistance.

Pseudohypoparathyroidism is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation of the alpha subunit of the Gs protein. This causes PTH resistance. It is associated with Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (short stature, round facies, and short fourth metacarpal).

Types of pseudohypoparathyroidism:

Type PHP 1A PHP 1B PHP 1C PHP 2 PPHP
Hypocalcemia Yes Yes Yes Yes No
Hyperphosphatemia Yes Yes Yes Yes No
PTH levels ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ Normal
GS α subunit deficiency Yes No  No No Yes
Albright hereditary osteodystrophy Yes No Yes No Yes
PTH resistance Yes Yes Yes Partial No

PHP: pseudohypoparathyroidism, PPHP: pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism, PTH: parathyroid hormone

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought by his mother with with the following abnormality. Serum levels of vitamin D are found to be low. Which of the following would not be seen in this boy?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a windswept deformity of the lower limbs (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg). This finding along with low serum vitamin D points to a diagnosis of vitamin D deficiency rickets. It is associated with an increase in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to hypocalcemia?
questions.solution:
Hypocalcemia is a feature of secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT).

Hypocalcemia refers to total serum calcium ≤8.4 mg/dl. The causes include:

  • Low PTH
    • Hypoparathyroidism
  • High PTH (SHPT)
    • Chronic kidney disease 
    • Vitamin D deficiency
    • Pseudohypoparathyroidism
    • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Loop diuretics, calcitonin, bisphosphonates
  • Massive blood transfusions
  • Hyperventilation
  • Hypomagnesemia - Mg is essential for PTH release
  • Severe hypermagnesemia - higher Mg levels suppress PTH secretion

Hypocalcemia causes tetany or increased neuromuscular excitability. It can cause paresthesias, cramps, spasms, and seizures. Latent tetany can only be detected by performing Chvostek and Trousseau's signs. A prolonged QT interval is seen on ECG.

questions.text: The following sign is elicited in a patient. What is it called?
questions.solution:
The above image indicates Trousseau's sign or carpopedal spasm classically seen in patients with hypocalcemia.

Trousseau's sign is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position.

Hypocalcemia results in tetany or increased neuromuscular irritability. It leads to paresthesia and tingling of extremities and perioral area. Severe hypocalcemia can cause seizures.

Option A: Chvostek's sign is also seen in hypocalcemia. Tapping the facial nerve in front of the tragus will cause spasms of the facial muscles. 

Option C: Tinel's sign is seen in carpal tunnel syndrome. It refers to a tingling sensation on tapping over the median nerve.

Option D: Troisier's sign refers to left supraclavicular lymphadenopathy in metastatic abdominal malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following agents cannot be used to manage a patient with chronic hypocalcemia?
questions.solution:
Etidronate is not used in the management of hypocalcemia. It is a bisphosphonate used in the management of hypercalcemia.

The goal in the management of hypoparathyroidism is to restore the calcium-phosphate balance. The mainstay is calcium and vitamin D supplements. Other underlying conditions must also be treated.

Instead of loop diuretics, thiazides can be administered on a low sodium diet as they enhance urinary calcium reabsorption.
